title: Before 1 August 2016, will the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approve release of the next tranche of its loan to Ukraine?
preds:
NATO leaders agreed to provide a comprehensive assistance package to Ukraine to support the country’s government in efforts to ensure closer cooperation with the alliance and combat Russia-backed insurgents in eastern Ukraine.
http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/omr/roadtowarsaw/2016/07/09/nato-approves-assistance-package-ukraine-condemns-russian-aggression/86897150/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Warsaw%201&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Digital%20Show%20Daily
had the info, didn't know what to do with it.
Lowering my forecast since we are now running out of time, but really, the IMF needs to get on the ball and get this money flowing to Ukraine.

News came too late to me - the decisions seems to be pushed back into August. “I think there will be an IMF board meeting in August and there will be a positive decision” for Ukraine on the next portion of its $17.5 billion rescue package, Danylyuk said Thursday in a live TV broadcast from Kiev. “We have done a lot, and the board understands this.”
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-21/imf-may-not-approve-ukraine-s-tranche-in-july-minister-says

IMF just released (three days ago) a position paper with legislative (market regulatory reforms) recommendations; these won't be acted upon by the end of July by the Ukraine legislature so releasing the third tranche should not happen.
It has become more of a political decision than economic one. Too many conditions to be met before July 31st

Not happening before the end of the month.  The IMF is said to be delaying their decision on the aid tranche that was expected in July and will reconsider theire decision at their August board meeting.  (According to Ukraine's Finance Minister Oleksandr Danylyuk, several laws still need to be approved by parliament and IMF is waiting on that.   IMF May Not Approve Ukraine’s Tranche in July, Minister Says
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-21/imf-may-not-approve-ukraine-s-tranche-in-july-minister-says

From Interfax // http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/359054.html ; July 21st
"Ukraine expects that the Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) at a meeting in August would make a positive decision regarding the resumption of financing of the credit program, Ukrainian Finance Minister Oleksandr Danyliuk has told reporters. He said that before the meeting Ukraine will be able to settle all technical issues left unsolved. "We have done many things… I think that in August a meeting of the board will be held and the creative decision will be," Danyliuk said."

http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/omr/roadtowarsaw/2016/07/09/nato-approves-assistance-package-ukraine-condemns-russian-aggression/86897150/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Warsaw%201&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Digital%20Show%20Daily had i CAUGHT THIS EARLIER i WOULD HAVE ZEROED OUT THE CHANGES OF GETTING THE TRANCHE ON TIME.

The International Monetary Fund may delay a board decision on Ukraine’s next aid tranche, previously expected in July, and consider disbursement next month, according to Finance Minister Oleksandr Danylyuk, as several laws still need to be approved by parliament. Only 10 days left. Unlikely in the short time period left. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-21/imf-may-not-approve-ukraine-s-tranche-in-july-minister-says
The release of funds for Ukraine is not on the agenda of any of the IMF meetings in July
Updating for passage of time & absence from agenda

Thanks to @sevedb and several others who have pointed out Ukraine is still not on the IMF Executive Board's calendar for the next seven days (though I'm surprised that the calendar also says "Last update June 23 2016")
http://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx?sort=date&year=

The last working day of the month is the 29th. A week ago, there were only 6 countries listed on the executive board calendar, and now they've added three more to the calendar. I'm inclined to believe they're not "last minute" adds/topics, just finalized scheduling. Right now, there is only one topic/country for the 29th, but multiple for the 20th, 22nd, and 27th... 
All that to say, I think there is technically still time to add Uk and room in the calendar to do so; however, as others have pointed out, some sources are indicating Uk itself is not exactly providing optimistic reports.  I'll flip to the other side of this, but am holding a little high until the beginning of next week.
Absence from the agenda is indeed ominous. Leaving a bit for a surprise.
Coming down hard on the article below and the great comments from others: http://uatoday.tv/politics/imf-loan-tranche-for-ukraine-delayed-700616.html
- 14 from 64 Still not on the IMF Executive Board Calendar http://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx?sort=country&year=
Not sure how reliable the source is: http://www.unian.info/economics/1427927-imf-loan-tranche-for-ukraine-delayed.html

Making a big reduction on this - the Ukrainians themselves don't sound very confident
http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/358168.html

Drastic reduction from 95%. I still believe the IMF will approve release of a tranche in the near future, but with just eleven days left to the deadline, it doesn't look like they are in any hurry to do so before the end of the month.

Feel this is doubtful.  Let's just say if this was a trade someone was pushing for and the deal was reform your government by drafting nineteen committee documents and we'll approve you for $1.7 bln USD before we  go on hole in two weeks time, I would be suspicious. plus coup  backing this: http://iportal.rada.gov.ua/en/news/News/133471.html Phone call between Porshenko and Lagarde also - I think he gave her an update, and she soothed concerns that the money was still there - pending reforms, and if not sooner, then after August.  I think it's after August.

- 1 from 65 
Still not on the IMF Executive Board Calendar http://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx?sort=country&year=

IMF chief spokesman Gerry Rice said some technical issues still needed to be resolved. Rice added that Ukraine's parliament did not need to pass any additional anti-corruption and transparency legislation in order for the board to consider the next $1.7 billion tranche. "Consideration could still be in July, the discussions are very close to being finalized," Rice told a regular news briefing. "There is no further legislation pending that is a condition for this review, but there are of course a number of laws that are to be adopted or to be amended that are important for the overall success of the program," Rice said. If approval is delayed, it may be considered again in mid-August, after the board's summer recess, Rice added.
http://www.reuters.com/article/imf-ukraine-idUSL1N1A00VO

http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/358168.html ""There is still likelihood that the board of directors could hold a meeting in July… If this happen in July, the money we will receive in August," the minister said on Inter TV.
Danyliuk said that only technical issues are left in the negotiations between Ukraine and the IMF.
He said that if Ukraine's issue is not settled in July, the board could discuss it at once after their vacation in late August." But I'm dropping because  I don't see it on this week's calendar.... so doesn't leave many days left:
https://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx

-10
Still not on the IMF Executive Board Calendar http://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx?sort=country&year=

-3
Excerpts as they related to Uk, from Friday July 14th, Press Brief: http://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2016/07/15/15/18/TR071516%20Transcript%20of%20the%20Press%20Briefing%20with%20Gerry%20Rice @sevedb, this seems fairly common non-committal response from Mr Rice; would you agree? "QUESTIONER: Thanks as always. I just wanted to, I guess get it out of the way quickly. My question is on Ukraine. Do we still have a chance to see a Board Meeting on Ukraine before the end of July as promised? What may be the expected result of that meeting? And when I was looking at my notes here, I realized we haven't mentioned the issue of the Russian debt for a while. So, do you know anything about any progress on the Russian debt issue, in the context of the problem? Thank you. MR. RICE: Yes. Thank you, Andrew. You know, I think it's possible that the Board will consider the next review, it could still be in July, or if it takes some more time, it would be after the Board's recess which is coming up. But Board consideration could still be in July, the discussions are very close to being finalized and you know, there are some technical issues that we expect to be resolved soon. On the debt, no material change from what I've communicated here before, Andrew. And of course it will be part of the Board's consideration, one of the aspects that will be considered by the Board when that discussion takes place. QUESTIONER: Thank you. I also have a question on Ukraine. This is the last week of work of Ukraine and parliamentarians still have not adopted the laws agreed earlier with IMF Mission. So including like tax and custom codes that we are agreed, so will it influence the decision of IMF of giving tranche, and if they start work on 6th of September. Thank you. MR. RICE: What I can tell you is, there is no further legislation pending that is a condition for this review. Okay? But there are of course, a number of laws that are to be adopted or amended over the next several months that are important for the overall success of the program. Okay? On Ukraine, yes.
Edging up slightly on the article below: http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/international-monetary-fund-imf-could-resume-aid-to-ukraine-in-july-spokesman-2914379/

Upping this slightly - IMF spokesman not guaranteeing anything though
http://www.reuters.com/article/imf-ukraine-idUSL1N1A00VO

The very latest news on this issue: http://www.reuters.com/article/imf-ukraine-idUSL1N1A00VO The finalization of the details needed for the next tranche to be released could come very soon indeed but the article also says: "If approval is delayed, it may be considered again in mid-August, after the board's summer recess, Rice added." Most of the news I've seen suggests it will come soon but I've also seen implications it might not, like this one. 80 seems a bit too low but 85 is too high. I will down 83 for this one until further notice.

"Finance Ministry says when IMF’s Exec Board to convene on Ukraine Finance Minister Oleksandr Danyluk has stressed that the certain difficulties in the Parliament’s work will not delay the decision of the International Monetary Fund on Ukraine. Read more on UNIAN: http://www.unian.info/economics/1413933-finance-ministry-says-when-imfs-board-of-directors-to-convene-on-ukraine.html" bumping up. Tranche likely to be awarded even if paperwork on legislation is still in process.
more political instabilty in region around ukraine means more likely money will be released

Loans expected to be released in parts which will allow for IMF to reward partial compliance with first expected in July.  Ukraine is making progress on subset of reforms making it unlikely for IMF to extend the timeline given option of partial distribution.

The negotiations are reported as being over so it's just up to the board to decide if all will go ahead: http://www.ukrainianjournal.com/index.php?w=article&id=23138 Reducing slightly just to reflect the slim timeframe.
Barring any rare events, keeping Ukraine afloat is a strategic objective.

As much as the IMF and its main donors would like to promote (or even push) anti-corruption and greater efforts at economic efficiency, they will not risk the potential damage to Ukraine and the risks of accelerating weakness. Ukraine is in a position of weakness but this will work to its advantage.
Both sides working for same goal.
I think we'll know more after the NATO Russia conference.

-6, feeling a little too confident and going to come down a little bit based on the tight turn between IMF summer recess.

-2  from 67
 after reading post https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/277476 from @Shiva «Alexander Paraschiy: The EU has repeatedly affirmed that its loan program’s renewal will be based on the real implementation of reforms, which will be assessed by the IMF. Yet the situation with next IMF wire remains uncertain. Though we do not see many impediments to a positive decision from the IMF Executive Board (all the painful steps have already been taken), Ukraine has yet to approve at least 19 legislative items required by the IMF.»
As of today, the likelihood of approving the bills in the near term is quite poor. We counted only three laws fully approved, and two approved only in the first reading. All the other bills are being drafted or have yet to pass parliamentary committees. Parliament needs to approve the legislation during the next two weeks before the summer break, otherwise funding from the IMF and EU will be delayed until at least September. Fortunately, the draft laws are mostly about technical changes and should not encounter political resistance. [1]

From an investment firm from Ukraine, with some credibility to loose, i think i most highly considered this opinion. But i cannot see the FMI stopping financing Ukraine. Maybe, have some little delay.

The release of funds is expected to happen this year after Ukraine "unveiled a comprehensive program of economic reforms, backed by a $17.01 billion IMF loan approved on April 30."  I've seen reports the release may happen in August or September.  Nothing certain.   I saw on Twitter that the economy in Ukraine continues to worsen.  As usual with this cases, the people blame the IMF deal.  A commission from the IMF visited the  country in May.  The IMF said at the time of its visit that  "resistance to allow civil society experts to play a role in establishing an anti-corruption bureau."    Here is IMF's Managing Director statement from February of this year:  “I am concerned about Ukraine’s slow progress in improving governance and fighting corruption, and reducing the influence of vested interests in policymaking.”  Ukraine Seen Resuming IMF Loan in Summer as Graft Ranking Stuck
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-06/ukraine-seen-resuming-imf-loan-in-summer-as-graft-ranking-stuck Transfers from the Washington-based lender, delayed for half a year, will restart in August, according to three of eight economists in a Bloomberg survey. Two said cooperation will be restored in June, while one each saw it happening in April, May or September." I will give it a 45% probability until we get closer to the IMF meeting later this month and get a better idea on what their decision will be.

With Brexit still creating chaos everywhere, anything to encourage stability in Ukraine is going to be a positive.  If the IMF does not release the funds, Ukraine may well collapse, and I don't see anybody pushing for that.  (Other than Putin, but the IMF doesn't really listen to him.)
Ukrainians believe a part of the tranche will be paid in July http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-and-imf-to-sign-memo-on-next-tranche-in-few-days-finance-minister-685279.html
not if loan is conditional on IMF reforms.

no credit for dead people

Only raising because the graph/stats are currently hovering over 80%, so I am probably missing something. But, I still think the EU "wants" to hold the dysfunctional Ukrainian parliament's feet to the fire, especially since so much of the chaos is connected to cronyism and outright corruption. I suppose it will be a close vote. Certainly, they don't want Ukraine to fail, but to let the country go on the way it is, is unsustainable, and the IMF will be in a worse decision point in the future if they let it pass now. As tough as it may be, it might be a better long-term solution to force an adherence to minimal economic/political standards. Again, the IMF has the flexibility to delay for any length of time and re-visit the decision whenever they want. Though.......As pointed out by others, the IMF could release a portion. Since the US portion is contingent on the IMF release occurring first, I  am not sure the impact if only a partial IMF tranche was released.

Revising this down - it's unlikely to be $1.7 billion and that's the full tranche of the payment

My prediction is based on my current odds of Hilary becoming President sadly she already spent $5 billion to instigate a coup in the Ukraine while Obama's Secretary of State.  Trump says a bunch of things but its hard to predict just what he will really do as President....he protest to much, as Hamlet's  mom would say.

This statement by Poroshenko lacks the confidence and fidelity I would like to hear in order to commit much higher.  'Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko hopes the issue of EU macro-financial assistance to Ukraine will be resolved in the near future. "We've agreed on macro-financial assistance. We hope the last two points will be settled in the near future. And after the IMF makes decision on granting the next tranche to Ukraine, the European Union will join this by providing Ukraine with macro-financial assistance along with loan guarantees to be given by the U.S.," the president told journalists after a mini-summit in Brussels.'
http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/353069.html And this excerpt continues to claim the reforms yet needed are complicated and still lack concrete parameters defined by the IMF.:
"An effective lever for the West is the loan of $17.5 billion that the International Monetary Fund allocated in March 2015, of which only $6.7 billion has been disbursed so far. A next tranche of $1.7 billion will be released when the IMF will have agreed with Ukraïne's additional reforms regarding monetary policy, pension-reform and privatisation of state companies. An effective fight against corruption is formally also a condition that the IMF puts to the Ukrainian government, but unclear is if the Fund has put concrete conditions and what these consist of exactly. The $ 1,7 billion wil not only replenish the reserves of Ukraïne's Central Bank, it will also unfreeze $ 4 billion of aid from the US, the EU and other donors. Some weeks ago the Groysman government managed to convince an IMF-mission that it would effectively carry through the requested reforms. The final decision will be taken by the IMF's Governing Board in July however. It is of the utmost importance that the Board put indeed concrete conditions for immediate and drastic reforms in the organisation of the Public Prosecutor, regarding the lustration of judges, in the fight against corruption measures and in the election-laws. That will make it also easier for the European Union, US and other donors to follow-up with similar demands."
http://www.kyivpost.com/article/opinion/op-ed/willem-gert-aldershoff-west-must-put-rock-hard-conditions-for-continued-aid-to-ukraine-417352.html Keeping me high is my interpretation that whatever the next tranche is, $10, $10M, or a loaf of bread, as long as it's approved by the IMF as the next tranche, it's gtg.

IMF will delay again to hold politicians' feet to the fire. Politicians are still fighting amongst themselves. Many of the reformer politicians have resigned recently. New charges of graft/corruption and offshore snakery. IMF has nor requirement to revisit the question x-date from now...in essence, the can revisit the question as often and at whatever schedule they want. Plus, there are extra US$ involved, dependent on the approval of IMF funds.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/ukraines-parliament-elects-new-government-amid-political-crisis/2016/04/14/ffdd2919-0312-4ced-89d8-402317002762_story.html

Updating as it sounds like any amount of the would be considered a valid tranche.
Reasoning:
* Ukraine now has a more stable government. They have been reforming their legislation, though very slowly.
* The milestones are not spelled out exactly. 
* There is already plenty of uncertainty in the market right before the most illiquid market period during the summer holidays. Withholding this loan would introduce more geopolitical uncertainty and push back any decision by a few months.

No.  Information about Ukraine's activities connected to terrorism against the United States will be either under investigation or revealed publically, which will prevent the IMF from releasing additional support.
IMF rarely overturns prelim decisions recently, US interest in keeping pro-West government, pro-EU movement after Brexit

IMF's first deputy managing director David Lipton "We reached an agreement on important issues, and there are several more issues to be agreed upon - said Lipton. - If the Ukrainian government and the IMF approve amendments, Ukraine will receive the next tranche in July or August".
http://uatoday.tv/business/ukraine-may-receive-next-tranche-in-july-august-imf-official-667539.html Still possible it might not happen by 1 August. But it seems unlikely, because of the USA's political decision making. The IMF Board of Governors will meet in July; the precise date has yet to be announced. The next tranche we are expecting to receive will reach $1 billion," she said, adding that a memorandum with the IMF had not been signed

the GJ question asks will the IMF release the next tranche of its loan to Ukraine by 1 Aug 16.  the question does not state a specific amount. The fact that the IMF is having a discussion about the amount indicates they are working towards a July release even if its a partial release.  And a yes for this question. +1
Given Brexit, the EU will want to delay this payment beyond August 1
Dropping due to the Brexit fallout and general financial insecurity.
The IMF might not provide the full tranche as the country is still in a flux and the money may not be spent well. Though the IMF will provide just enough for Ukraine to continue along.

The IMF board will meet in July and may approve an initial payment. It's unlikely to be the full tranche though.
http://in.reuters.com/article/ukraine-imf-idINKCN0Z12LQ
The Ukrainians expect that this will be the case. Ukraine has been much more politically stable in the last few months 
http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/352185.html
But the voices in this article don't sound too optimistic
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-21/ukraine-sees-imf-aid-at-less-than-third-its-projection-for-2016

Although it seems Ukraine is in a state of flux and it might not be the most prudent to provide more liquidity to them till they sort out their chain, there is too much at stake. The IMF might see it as a case of their inaction leading to more harm than providing them the cash flow which 'might' get wasted.

Much as the IMF was somehow persuaded to capitulate, or at least relax, on Greece in light of geopolitical considerations (i.e. let's not have another visible Greek debt crisis right when the Brits are voting on the referendum), I think in this case there will be pressure on the IMF to appear supportive of Ukraine. The EU's attention will be directed across the channel, appearing unified and batting down any more "populist" calls in other countries. I believe the Ms Lagarde and the IMF will be flexible if they need to.

+ 2 from 65 Extract from a transcript of a Press Briefing with Gerry Rice, Spokesman, IMF Communications Department
Washington DC
June 16, 2016 «question from UNIAN, the news agency in Ukraine, asking, "Did you have -- did you, the IMF, have meetings with Ukrainian Prime Minister? Is it clear when the Ukrainian issue will be discussed by the Board?" So, let me give a little status update. Actually, we met with the Finance Minister yesterday -- not the Prime Minister, the Finance Minister, Oleksandr Danylyuk, who visited the Fund yesterday, met with staff to discuss recent developments, as well as the remaining issued to be addressed before the Board consideration of the second review of the program.
When can we expect the Board to discuss that? We expect the Board to consider that in July, following implementation of actions to entrench fiscal and financial stability. So, I think that’s that question. Let me keep back in the room if there’s one or two.» [1] [2] [1] http://www.imf.org/external/np/tr/2016/tr061616.htm
[2] similar of https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/264933 Thanks to @HW15
If only to get at Russia.
Keeping mess from hurting Hillary in the election

On one hand, Ukraine is trying to comply with IMF requirements, but its politics, the political culture, recent political crisis with reformist ministers quitting provide huge obstacles. On the other hand, IMF tranche is already smaller than expected - the IMF hedges its risks. At the end, the IMF wants to keep Ukraine at least afloat - risks of its implosion are too big.

I would agree that this should be seen as politics first and economics second. The geopolitical mix around the Ukraine suggests that the West will not allow it to fall back in the Russian sphere.  Will update as info becomes available.
Western Countries wish to support the democratic process of Ukraine and try to support the economic development.

They'll most likely get it before 1 August, though a smaller amount than they wanted. From what I've read, it is also possible that the tranche will be split in two parts. The first part will be released immediately, the second part later, on condition of further reforms (like raising the retirement age, currently 60 years. Might go to 62-65). In the latter case, I do not expect this question to resolve as "yes", since it is a delay in the approval decision.

IMF loans aren't made on strictly economic grounds. It is in the West's interest to ensure that Ukraine's economy doesn't collapse, pushing the country back into the Russian sphere. Even if Ukraine does not meet all criteria, the loan will almost certainly be released (with waivers).

http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/348481.html This is the third tranche. Two have already been doled out without Ukraine having to change its tune. This batch will be no different. The meeting is set for "Early July"

This is pure politics, the USA is showing its political support to the Ukraine no matter what. Given that the Ukraine has met the preconditions, I expect it to be approved. Ukraine approves 2016 budget, clearing way for delayed IMF loan
http://www.dw.com/en/ukraine-approves-2016-budget-clearing-way-for-delayed-imf-loan/a-18941631

Europe and the U.S. are not lenders by choice but by necessity.  The corruption in the government will continue to be a sore point but the alternative would be an economic collapse.  I do not believe even Russia wants that to happen.  A terrible decision that will be taken to avoid an even worse situation.

It seems like Ukraine desperately needs money and IMF is the vehicle that international community designated for this type of operations, so unless Ukraine does something completely outrageous, the tranche will be approved.

Reducing the amount released would still be "release of the next tranche", right?? Or would that be a delay of the "review process"? A sketchy source, but a possibility..."On June 6, the apostrophe.com.ua news site cited an anonymous source in the Ukrainian government as saying the IMF is considering reducing the next tranche to $1bn."
http://www.intellinews.com/imf-to-decide-size-of-ukraine-s-delayed-loan-tranche-in-july-99259/ But in this quote Ukraine doesn't look too confident:"“We will see what decision the IMF will make,” Hroisman said. “The budget year ends Dec. 31, so I don’t see any special difference in when we get the money and how much.”
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-21/ukraine-sees-imf-aid-at-less-than-third-its-projection-for-2016 And this article looks like the IMF will probably give it...
http://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine-politics/vacher-too-soon-to-say-whether-imf-will-restart-lending-program-to-ukraine-415400.html So I should probably start at 50%... but hate doing that. Until someone convinces me otherwise I will assume that ANY amount of support from the IMF will count, as long as it is on time (even if less than expected). So that pushes me a little higher. And I guess I believe the West REALLY wants to support Ukraine to show that breakaways from Russia can be successful. So I'm jumping in moderately high
At least to get started....

зајам остаје као врста политичког притиска за Украјину на političkom i svakom drugom nivou
Niko se u politici ne odriče dobrog sredstva za pritisak
